awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Scalable Algorithms for Data and Network Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Data-based decision-making involving big input data sets require a lot of time for algorithms to process them. In computer science, efficient algorithms are generally considered to be the ones whose running time does not increase "too fast" when input size grows. "Scalable algorithms" are among the most efficient algorithms, because their running time is required to be nearly linear or even sub-linear with respect to the problem size. In other words, their complexity scales gracefully when the input size scales up. In the age of Big Data, efficient algorithms are in higher demand now more than ever before. While big data takes us into the asymptotic world envisioned by the pioneers of computer science, the explosive growth of problem size has also significantly challenged the classical notion of efficient algorithms: Algorithms that used to be considered efficient, according to the traditional polynomial-time characterization, may no longer be adequate for solving today's problems. It is not just desirable, but essential, that efficient algorithms should be scalable. Thus, scalability, instead of polynomial-time computability, should be elevated to the central complexity notion for characterizing efficient computation, and this will be the focus of algorithm design for network sciences and big data. This project will focus on the design and analysis of scalable algorithms.  One of its primary objective is to build bridges between the area of algorithm design and the fields of network sciences and machine learning.  If successful, the project will help to provide a rigorous algorithmic framework for designing new scalable data and network analysis algorithms.  By focusing on notions of algorithmic efficiency --- such as scalability --- that respect the sensibilities of researchers in these disciplines as to what constitutes a practical algorithm in the age of big data, this project aims to increase the value of theoretical analyses to researchers in these fields.  As this project combines ideas from many disciplines within one coherent research effort, lectures and tutorials presented on the fruits of the project will help cross-fertilize the disciplines within its scope.  The development of theoretical algorithms that might have practical applicability should simplify education in algorithms for students beyond theoretical computer science, and allow discussion of practically important heuristics at early stages of computer science education. The interdisciplinary nature of this research will enable broader engagements with PhD students and researchers in network sciences, machine learning, numerical analysis, and social science and hence will enhance the chance to be successful in supporting and working with women and minority researchers.

The technical goal of this project is to systematically extend the family of algebraic, numerical, and combinatorial techniques from the recent breakthroughs in Laplacian linear solvers and max-flows/min-cuts, to a wide-range of problems that arise in network analysis, data mining, and machine learning.  This project aims to show that these techniques --- including advanced sampling, sparsification, and local exploration of networks --- will play increasing roles in improving algorithmic scalability.  It contains several open questions and conjectures ranging from network analysis to distribution sampling to social influences towards this goal.  By providing new algorithmic insights into various dynamic processes over graphs, the project also aims to improve the understanding of network facets beyond static graph structures in order to develop better algorithmic theory for network sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This has been a fruitful and learning project at the intersection of Network Sciences, Game Theory, and Stochastic Modeling. Our research, through the lens of scalable algorithm design, studies a wide range of structures beyond traditionally considered mathematical structures. In addition to graph, matrices, and metrics, we have studied：

(a) Sparse Models: such as operators in quantum logic syntheses, and distribution and topological structures in machine learning.

(b) Dense Models: such as Personalized PageRank matrices in Web search and social network clustering.

(c) BIG Models: such as exponentially sized game trees, set functions, multi-battleground games, and stochastic influences profiles.

Many of the structures we considered involve interplays between two or multiple basic structures. For example: (1) Social influence can be viewed as the interplay of dynamics process and static network structures; (2) Machine learning introduces interplay between distributions and mass transport; (3) Quantum logic synthesis interacts algebraic operators with topological connectivity. (4) Mathematical games capture the strategic decision between two players’ deep logic structures.

The proposed research uncovered several efficient algorithmic solutions for network analysis, (quantum) logic synthesis, and combinatorial games. Beyond algorithmic research, we have also developed some mathematical theory to characterize solution concepts for complex interplays among  multifaceted data models. 

Intellectual Merit:

 In network analysis, we have made progress both in algorithm design and mathematical characterization of solution concepts. Mathematically, we have focused on axiomatic characterization of influence centralities that reflect group-based influence in social network. We have established novel interdisciplinary connection with cooperative game theory (via the classical Shapley value) and social-choice theory (via axiomatic representation of solution concepts). In an analog of Fourier representations of (Boolean) functions, we have discovered a surprising deterministic graph-theoretical basis for stochastic influence profiles. Algorithmically, we have showed that scalable techniques from PageRank approximations and influence maximization can be used to approximate social-influence Shapley values, whose exact computation is #P hard.

In combinatorial game theory, we have settled two long-standing complexity-theoretical questions—open since 1981 and 1993—which have significant computational ramification to the celebrated classical Sprague-Grundy Theory developed in 1930s. Our new results concern the complexity leap in the sum of two polynomial-time solvable mathematical board games. It highlights the fundamental computational challenge in natural problems with succinctly represented big models and deep logic. We have also made systematic progress on “quantum-inspired” mathematical games.

In statistical analysis, a student from our group completed his Ph.D. thesis, titled, “Information Geometry and Optimal Transport”, wining the best paper award at 2019 Geometric Science of Information Conference, by establishing a significant and a beautiful connection between information geometry and optimal transport. The work has both mathematical and algorithmic implications.

In quantum logic synthesis, we have developed an efficient algorithm for achieving asymptotically optimal trade-off between additional qubits (known as ancillae) and the depth of quantum circuits.

In game theory, we obtained several basic results for understanding the algorithmic and complexity challenges of strategical optimization in multi-battleground competition with heterogeneous, multifaceted resources, significantly generalizing the classical Colonel Blotto games.

Broader Impacts:

We have had successful multi-disciplinary collaborations with researchers outside traditional TCS fields. Wei Chen (of Data Mining) and Hanrui Zhang (of AI) and I worked together on characterizing network influence models and developing influence analysis algorithms. We also applied the axiomatization frameworks from social-choice theory and cooperative game theory to network analysis. Jiaqing Jiang, Xiaoming Sun, Bujiao Wu (of Quantum Computing) and I worked with two TCS researchers on developing optimal synthesis algorithms, based on linear algebraic techniques, for quantum logic circuits. Our work on combinatorial game theory also led us to an active collaboration with Canadian Mathematician Svenja Huntemann. These joint efforts, in addition to enhancing our own knowledge of subjects outside theoretical computer science, help to expanding computational thinking to other fields.

Some of the research of this project also found delightful applications in K-12 education. For example, in the Spring of 2022, I was invited to give a lecture on the board game NIM to teach mathematical induction to third grade elementary school students (about half the young mathematicians are girls) at UCLA Math Circle. It’s wonderful to see the magic smile on these young mathematicians’ face when they discovered on their own a winning trick and logic. 

*Ph.D. Mentoring:

•   Jiaowen Yang,  USC (Math) defended Ph.D. thesis, “Information Geometry and Optimal Transport.”

•   Matt Ferland made great progresses towards his Ph.D.

*Award: (a) 2022 KDD Keynote Speaker; (b) 2022 ACM SIGECOM Test of Time Award (for settling the approximation complexity of Nash equilibrium, with Xi Chen and Xiaotie Deng); (c) SIAM Fellow (2021); (d) 2021 ACM STOC Test of Time Award (for developing smoothed analysis, with Dan Spielman); (e) USC Associates Award for Creativity in Research and Scholarship (2021); (f) Phi Kappa Phi Faculty Recognition Award (2020) -- for his book, “Scalable Algorithms for Data and Network Analysis”.
